Article Title: Godfather of AI: Bill Gates and Elon Musk right about AI replacing humans, but they forget that ...
Article Text:
Geoffrey Hinton’s warning: Jobs at Risk

AI-Powered Future: Next Gen Careers You Should Watch

Economics of AI under scrutiny

Job and humanity at risk





Godfather of AI Geoffrey Hinton is back with another prediction of AI. Hinton believes that AI will lead to massive unemployment. Recently, Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said that AI will not lead to mass layoffs, but it will transform the nature of various jobs. On the other hand, Bill Gates feels that humans may soon not be needed “for most things,” while Elon Musk believes most people won’t have to work at all within 20 years. But Godfather of AI feels that all these predictions are overlooking one major reality that AI may cause economic upheaval which may lead to mass unemployment.As reported by Fortune, speaking at the Georgetown University along with Bernie Sanders, Hinton said that the rise of AI could leave millions of workers behind. “It seems very likely to a large number of people that we will get massive unemployment caused by AI,” he said.Hinton further noted that the tech giants are busy investing trillions in data centres and chips and are heavily betting on AI systems which can replace human labor at lower cost. Hinton has become increasingly vocal about what he sees as Big Tech’s misplaced priorities, arguing that the industry is driven more by short-term profits than scientific progress.The financial realities of AI are also becoming a cause of concern. ChatGPT creator OpenAI is not expected to turn a profit until at least 2030 and may need more than $207 billion to sustain growth, according to HSBC estimates.Godfather of AI, who left Google in 2023 in order to speak freely about the risks of AI. He warned that AI will lead to new job creation but it will not offset the scale of losses. “Trying to predict the future of it is going to be very difficult,” he said, likening the uncertainty to driving in fog.Same has Bill Gates, Bernie Sanders also echoed the warnings from tech leaders including Tesla CEO Elon Musk and Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei that AI could displace millions of jobs. “If I’m a factory worker today, if I’m working in an office, how am I going to feed my family? How am I going to pay the rent? Who is talking about that?”Sanders also raised concerns about AI’s impact on human relationships, noting that teenagers increasingly rely on AI companions. “If kids today have AI as their best friends… what kind of change does that mean for humanity?”Sanders also warned about the cooperation between AI companies and the U.S. military could erode privacy. “How far away are we from a small number of people having access to the email that you’ve sent out, every phone call that you’ve been on, really every aspect of your life? We’re not far.”While Gates and Musk envision a future where humans are freed from work, Hinton insists the conversation must also address the social and economic consequences of mass displacement.
Article Summary: Godfather of AI Geoffrey Hinton believes that AI will lead to massive unemployment. Hinton has become increasingly vocal about what he sees as Big Tech’s misplaced priorities. He warned that the industry is driven more by short-term profits than scientific progress.

Article Title: Machine learning fuels credit boom in India as 93% of lenders claims higher approvals: Report
Article Text:
ML drives financial inclusion and lowers bad debt: Report





How AI gets smart: Unlocking LLMs

Automation and GenAI emerge as top benefits





What are the Barriers to AI and ML adoption









A new study by Experian, conducted by Forrester Consulting, reveals that Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are transforming credit decisioning in India. The technologies are helping financial institutions to expand access to credit and improve portfolio quality. Based on input from 109 senior credit risk decision makers in India, the findings indicate that ML is becoming a strategic asset for growth in the rapidly digitalizing lending landscape.The research highlights a dual impact from ML adoption: increasing financial inclusion while enhancing risk management:Higher approvals: 93% of ML users focusing on vehicle loans reported higher approval rates.Reduced bad debt: 90% of lenders using ML for credit cards have successfully reduced bad debt.New segments: 79% of ML adopters agree that the technology allows them to responsibly serve new customer segments—including thin-file and new-to-credit consumers—who were often excluded by traditional scorecards.Improved profitability: 71% of respondents reported that ML improves overall profitability by enhancing risk prediction.Lenders are leveraging ML to accelerate their digital processes, with key benefits being efficiency and speed:Operational efficiency: Nearly 68% of ML users cite improved risk prediction accuracy and operational efficiency as key benefits.Increased automation: 71% agree that ML enables them to automate more credit decisions, reducing manual workloads.Future outlook: Looking ahead, 78% of respondents believe that the majority of credit decisions will be fully automated within five years.The report also said that Generative AI (GenAI) is emerging as a powerful productivity tool as 84% of respondents believe GenAI can significantly reduce the time and effort required to develop and deploy new credit risk models. Meanwhile, 70% agree that GenAI’s biggest advantage is streamlining regulatory documentation, which accelerates validation cycles.Despite the proven advantages, the report reveals that many organizations remain cautious, leading to persistent barriers to wider ML adoption, including cost concern, lack of understanding, compliance and infrastructure
Article Summary: A new study by Experian, conducted by Forrester Consulting, reveals that Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are transforming credit decisioning in India. The findings indicate that ML is becoming a strategic asset for growth in the rapidly digitalizing lending landscape.

Article Title: Half of manufacturers now stop ransomware before encryption, Sophos reports
Article Text:
Manufacturers are successfully blocking more ransomware before data gets encrypted, a positive shift. However, cybercriminals are now focusing on stealing data and demanding ransoms without encryption. Despite improved recovery times and reduced costs, a significant number still pay, highlighting the evolving threat landscape and internal security challenges.

Recovery improves despite ongoing threats





Manufacturing companies are stopping more ransomware attacks before encryption occurs, but cybercriminals are responding by increasingly stealing data and resorting to extortion-only tactics, according to a new Sophos report.The study found that only 40% of attacks on manufacturers resulted in data encryption—the lowest level in five years and a sharp drop from 74% last year. However, this defensive progress comes with a caveat: extortion-only attacks surged to 10% from just 3% in 2024, as attackers pivot their strategies to maintain leverage over victims.The report, based on a survey of 332 manufacturing organizations hit by ransomware in the past year, revealed that half of manufacturers successfully stopped attacks before encryption could occur—more than double last year's 24%. Despite this improvement, 51% of affected organizations still paid ransoms, with a median payment of $1 million against demands averaging $1.2 million.Recovery metrics showed positive trends, with 58% of manufacturers fully recovering within one week, up from 44% previously. Average recovery costs, excluding ransom payments, declined 24% to $1.3 million.Sophos X-Ops identified Akira, Qilin, and PLAY as the most active ransomware groups targeting manufacturing over the past year, with 99 distinct threat groups observed across leak sites.Data theft remained a significant concern, affecting 39% of manufacturers who experienced encryption—one of the highest rates across all sectors surveyed.Internal vulnerabilities continue to plague the industry, with 42.5% of organizations citing lack of expertise, 41.6% pointing to unknown security gaps, and 41% identifying inadequate protection as contributing factors.The human toll was also evident: 47% of manufacturers reported increased team stress following encryption incidents, while 44% faced increased pressure from senior leadership and 27% experienced leadership changes as a result of attacks.
Article Summary: Manufacturing companies are stopping more ransomware attacks before encryption occurs. Cybercriminals are responding by increasingly stealing data and resorting to extortion-only tactics. Despite improved recovery times and reduced costs, a significant number still pay, highlighting the evolving threat landscape and internal security challenges.

Article Title: Pentagon watchdog 'agrees': Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth was 'wrong' in using Signal messaging app
Article Text:
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth listens as President Donald Trump speaks during a Cabinet meeting at the White House, in Washington. (AP Photo/Julia Demaree Nikhinson)

Under Fire Over ‘Kill All’ Order, Hegseth TORCHES Narco-terrorists At Pentagon Xmas Tree Lighting

The Signal chats and The Atlantic leak





A Pentagon inspector general investigation has concluded that Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth placed U.S. personnel and their mission at risk by using the Signal messaging app to transmit sensitive details regarding a military strike against Houthi militants in Yemen, according to two people familiar with the findings who spoke to The Associated Press. While the report found that Hegseth violated Pentagon policy by conducting official business on a personal device, it did not conclude that he improperly declassified material, noting his broad authority as Defense Secretary to do so.According to the sources speaking to the news agency AP, the watchdog found that Hegseth shared operational details—including exact timings of warplane launches and bomb drops—before the pilots conducting the strikes were even airborne.Pentagon Chief Spokesman Sean Parnell stated: "The Inspector General review is a TOTAL exoneration of Secretary Hegseth and proves what we knew all along - no classified information was shared. This matter is resolved, and the case is closed." The White House also signaled its support, with Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt stating that President Donald Trump "stands by" Hegseth, noting the probe confirmed that operational security was not compromised.Hegseth’s use of the encrypted app -- which is not authorized for classified military communications—faced scrutiny after journalist Jeffrey Goldberg of The Atlantic was inadvertently added to a chat thread by then-National Security Adviser Mike Waltz.The chat, intended to discuss March 15 operations against Iran-backed Houthis, included high-profile officials such as Vice President JD Vance, Secretary of State Marco Rubio, and Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard.In addition to this group, report says that Hegseth created a separate Signal chat with 13 people, including his wife and brother, where he shared similar specific details about the impending strikes.Multiple current and former military officials told the AP that sharing such specific details on an unsecured device, particularly regarding "strike windows" and "target terrorists" before an attack occurred, would typically be strictly prohibited.The investigation faced hurdles regarding evidence collection. One source told the AP that the Inspector General had to rely on screenshots of the chat published by The Atlantic because Hegseth could not provide more than a handful of his own messages.Furthermore, Hegseth declined to be interviewed by the Pentagon’s inspector general. Instead, he provided a written statement asserting he was permitted to declassify information as he saw fit and believed the details he shared would not endanger the mission.The report was delivered to lawmakers in a classified setting, with a redacted public version expected later this week. The findings have intensified partisan divides regarding Hegseth’s leadership.
Article Summary: Pentagon inspector general finds Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth violated Pentagon policy by using Signal messaging app to transmit sensitive details about a military strike against Houthi militants in Yemen. The report did not conclude that he improperly declassified material, noting his broad authority as Defense Secretary to do so. The White House signaled its support, with Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt stating that President Donald Trump "stands by" Heg seth.

Article Title: Donald Trump's NASA nominee Jared Isaacman makes a 'China promise' to America in new Moon race
Article Text:
Jared Isaacman, President Donald Trump's pick to be NASA Administrator, speaks during a hearing of the Senate Commerce, Science, and Transportation on Capitol Hill, Wednesday, Dec. 3, 2025, in Washington. (AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein)

From Mars to Moon: Change in priorities for Isaacman





Jared Isaacman, US President Donald Trump's NASA administrator nominee has made a 'China promise' to Americans. Trump's two-time appointee to lead NASA has said that it was his goal that the United States beat rival China in the race to return humans to the Moon, during a Senate confirmation hearing. The 42-year-old billionaire entrepreneur and private astronaut appeared during a rare second confirmation hearing that followed Trump's re-nomination of him in November for the top post at the US space agency.Isaacman reportedly told Senators that, if confirmed for the job, he would ensure the success of the Artemis lunar exploration program started in 2017, during Trump's first administration. "America will return to the Moon before our great rival (China), and we will establish an enduring presence to understand and realize the scientific, economic and national security value on the lunar surface," Isaacman said. Isaacman also committed to ensuring that there is no gap between the retirement of the International Space Station (ISS) and commercial Low Earth Orbit destinations. "We can never accept a gap in our capabilities again," said soon-to-be NASA head, "Not in Low Earth Orbit, or in our ability to reach the Moon."NASA's Artemis program to return to the Moon, however, has faced numerous delays in recent years. Experts warned in September that the lunar lander developed by Musk's SpaceX might not be ready in time.Such a complication would put the United States at risk of being overtaken by China, which also aims to reach the Moon by 2030. "I think it's imperative that we do so, and failing to do so calls into question American exceptionalism beyond just our expertise in the high ground of space," Isaacman said.During his first confirmation hearing in April, Isaacman reportedly stated that he wanted to prioritize sending astronauts to Mars. however, this week, he spoke more cautiously about Mars and more strongly emphasized the goal of returning a manned US mission to the Moon as soon as possible.Isaacman is a close associate of Tesla CEO Elon Musk . In fact, Isaacman nomination is said to reflect the Trump's on-again, off-again relationship with Musk, the world's richest man and founder of SpaceX, among other ventures. Trump's decision to withdraw Isaacman's first nomination took place as the president feuded in the spring with Musk, who had headed Trump's so-called Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE). Trump and Musk appear to have since reconciled.Since the rift between the US president and Elon Musk, who has openly spoken about his plans for the red planet, US authorities have been emphasizing their determination to outpace Beijing in what they call the "second space race." If confirmed to head NASA, Isaacman would need to ensure that SpaceX delivers the lunar lander on time.Asked about a potential conflict of interest with Musk, with whom he is reportedly very close, Isaacman assured that he maintains only professional relations with him. "Senators, I'm not here for a personal gain to favor or enrich contractors," Isaacman reportedly said.
Article Summary: Jared Isaacman, US President Donald Trump's NASA administrator nominee has made a 'China promise' to Americans. Isaacman reportedly told Senators that, if confirmed for the job, he would ensure the success of the Artemis lunar exploration program started in 2017.

“Foxconn is uniquely positioned to support OpenAI’s mission with trusted, scalable infrastructure,”





ChatGPT-maker OpenAI is partnering with Taiwan's Foxconn to design and build artificial intelligence (AI) data centre components within the US. This partnership is the AI startup's newest step in its extensive infrastructure development plans. The companies stated the goal is to accelerate infrastructure deployment and secure long-term US capacity for essential AI components. While financial terms were not disclosed, OpenAI confirmed it will have early access to evaluate the systems produced by the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer and Apple ’s largest supplier, along with the option to purchase them.In a statement to CNBC, OpenAI CEO Sam Altman commented on the partnership, saying:adding that AI infrastructure presents aUnder the agreement, OpenAI and Foxconn will co-develop multiple generations of AI servers and manufacture core components, which include power, networking, and cooling systems, at Foxconn’s US facilities, which are located in Wisconsin, Ohio, Texas, Virginia and Indiana.Foxconn adds another manufacturing layer to OpenAI’s supply chain, which could help make production for the AI startup more local and speed up deployment. The company is widely known for assembling Apple’s iPhones, but it has also expanded into AI and automotive manufacturing. It builds server racks designed for AI workloads and is an important global supplier to Nvidia, a major producer of high-end AI chips.Chairman Young Liu said to CNBC.However, the company has had mixed results in the US. In 2018, Foxconn began construction of a large factory in Wisconsin intended to make flat-panel displays. The project did not succeed, and the site is now being used for an AI data centre under construction by Microsoft.OpenAI has recently made several major agreements with some of the world’s biggest technology companies, announcing spending plans of about $1.4 trillion.These commitments have raised questions about whether the company will eventually generate enough profit to support that level of investment.Earlier this month, Altman said the company expects to reach $20 billion in annualised revenue by the end of the year and aims to reach hundreds of billions by 2030.Previous deals include a $100 billion agreement (yet to be finalised) with Nvidia, under which the chipmaker would invest in OpenAI in phases as the company expands its infrastructure.OpenAI also has cloud partnerships with Microsoft, Google, and Amazon, as well as significant compute buildout commitments with Oracle.
Article Summary: AI startup OpenAI is partnering with Taiwan's Foxconn to design and build artificial intelligence (AI) data centre components within the US. Article Title: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang to employees at town hall: Market not happy with our results, did you check memes on the internet
Article Text:
Nvidia’s quarterly results







Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang recently struck a humorous and candid tone in the company’s recent Townhall with the employees. Huang acknowledged that despite delivering a record-shattering earnings, the market reaction was less enthusiastic. As reported by Business Insider, Huang said that Nvidia’s influence has created a no-win situation with expectations so hight that even minor missteps could shake global markets. Huang also talked about the online chatter and memes about the company’s economic role. “If we delivered a bad quarter, if we’re off by just a hair, if it just looked a little bit creaky, the whole world would’ve fallen apart. You should’ve seen some of the memes on the internet. We’re basically holding the planet together — and it’s not untrue.”Nvidia reported a record quarter with $57 billion revenue which is up by 62% year-over-year, and forecasted $65 billion for the fourth quarter. The shares of the company rose by 5% in after-hours trading. Nvidia CFO Colette Kress reinforced the bullish outlook, noting, “The clouds are sold out. Our GPU installed base is fully utilized.”Nvidia’s blockbuster quarterly results rebuffs the growing narratives of an AI bubble.“If we delivered a bad quarter, it is evidence there’s an AI bubble. If we delivered a great quarter, we are fueling the AI bubble,” Huang told employees, according to a Business Insider report.Along with this, Huang also said that he was ‘delighted’ with the company’s results and proud of employees. He further added that Nvidia’s massive influence has made expectations harder to meet a reality reflected in its volatile market value.Huang lightheartedly recalled the “good old days” when Nvidia’s market cap stood at $5 trillion, joking about the company’s recent valuation swings, “Nobody in history has ever lost $500 billion in a few weeks. You’ve gotta be worth a lot to lose $500 billion in a few weeks.”

‘Musk’s demands to increase sales pushed resignations’







John Nitti, the global head of revenue operations and advertising innovation at X (formerly Twitter ), has departed the social media platform after only 10 months. His exit marks the latest senior-level departure from Elon Musk ’s executive ranks and comes just months after he was viewed by industry insiders as a potential successor to former CEO Linda Yaccarino, a report has said.Nitti, a former Verizon executive, left X on Friday (October 24), The Financial Times reported citing people familiar with the matter. His departure follows Yaccarino’s resignation in July, after which her duties were divided among several leaders, including Nitti.Nitti’s exit reflects an ongoing wave of senior executive departures since Musk’s AI startup, xAI, took over the social media platform in March. The resignations have reportedly been attributed to frustration over Musk’s sudden strategy changes and the difficulty of executing objectives under his management style.Other recent high-profile departures include:It is also being reported that there has been a constant pressure to boost revenues, which, combined with Musk’s simultaneous spending of billions on infrastructure for the AI race, fueled the resignations.The report said that advertising executives like Nitti have faced intense demands from Musk to increase sales, even as many advertisers have pulled back. Brands were deterred by Musk’s decision to relax content moderation standards based on his "free speech" ideals.The report cites sources as saying that Nitti was among sales leaders who grew frustrated with Musk’s management of the advertising business. Following the CEO’s disengagement from the Trump administration this past summer, Musk began making more unilateral decisions around advertising without consulting his leadership team.While xAI has recently secured new media partnerships, including one with Disney, and claims improving advertising metrics due to its AI technology, some advertisers privately complain they felt pressured to spend after X sued several brands for allegedly undertaking an "illegal boycott."

Microsoft has confirmed that it is internally testing an ad-supported, free version of Xbox Cloud Gaming, which will allow users to stream select titles without requiring a paid Game Pass subscription. Article Title: NASSCOM president Rajesh Nambiar on H-1B visa fee hike: Good news is that we have ...
Article Text:
Beyond visas, the sector is undergoing structural shifts driven by AI adoption and workforce transformation.

Donald Trump's Stricter H-1B Visa Rule Hits Indian Talent, Background Check Screening Expanded

India to become the world’s largest hub for AI skills





Recent changes to the America's H-1B visa programme are unlikely to significantly disrupt large Indian IT services companies, despite initial industry concerns, Nasscom president Rajesh Nambiar told The Economic Times. Nambiar said that major companies have already reduced dependence on H-1B visas over the years through increased local hiring in the United States. He also welcomed a clarification that international students in the U.S. on Optional Practical Training (OPT) extensions will be exempt from a proposed $100,000 visa fee.Another proposed shift — prioritising specialised, high-salary roles in the annual H-1B lottery — could raise visa costs, but the overall impact on IT services exporters will be “very minimal,” he said. Companies will continue to use H-1Bs for niche roles, he added, noting that the one-year window before the 2026 lottery gives firms time to ramp up domestic hiring. "Lot of local hiring already began several years ago. Good news is that we have a one year timeframe -- from the time it was announced to when the 2026 lottery will happen. This timeframe is enough for companies to ramp up (local hiring) because it's important," he added.While the United States will continue to be the Indian IT industry’s largest market, Nambiar expects newer regions such as Germany to offer growing opportunities.Startups — especially those in AI — face tougher challenges under stricter U.S. visa rules and global competition for specialised talent. Nambiar said emerging companies are increasingly turning to hybrid models, combining local hiring in overseas markets with remote execution from India.Beyond visa policies, Nambiar highlighted deeper structural changes underway in the global technology sector, driven by artificial intelligence and workforce transformation. Companies are increasingly reskilling employees for AI-enabled roles as older skill sets lose relevance. With a 6-million-strong tech talent base, India is well positioned to become the world’s largest hub for AI skills, he said, provided industry, academia and the government work in tandem.The talent mix in the sector is also shifting. While 65–70% of engineering graduates still specialise in computer science or related fields, Nambiar said future demand will favour professionals who combine technical expertise with domain knowledge and AI application skills. The industry added 30,000–40,000 fresh graduates in the first half of the fiscal year, though employment growth continues to lag revenue expansion as productivity rises with AI adoption.Despite rapid advances in automation, he stressed that human expertise remains indispensable. As with enterprise software rollouts like ERP, AI adoption in large organisations will require significant integration and oversight. “Humans remain central,” he said.
Article Summary: Recent changes to the America's H-1B visa programme are unlikely to significantly disrupt large Indian IT services companies. Nasscom president Rajesh Nambiar said that major companies have already reduced dependence on visas over the years.Beyond visas, the sector is undergoing structural shifts driven by AI adoption and workforce transformation.

Article Title: Meta faces investigation in EU over WhatsApp 'banning' AI chatbots
Article Text:
European regulators have launched a probe into Meta's move to block third-party AI services from its WhatsApp business tools, suspecting an abuse of dominance. This policy, effective early next year, favors Meta's own AI while forcing rivals like ChatGPT and Copilot out. Authorities aim to protect competition in the burgeoning AI sector.

ChatGPT and Copilot among services affected

EU’s investigation mirrors Italian antitrust probe





The European Commission launched a formal antitrust investigation into Meta Platforms' policy restricting third-party artificial intelligence providers from accessing WhatsApp 's business messaging tools, raising concerns the tech giant may be abusing its dominant position to favor its own AI service.The investigation centers on Meta's October 2025 policy change that prohibits AI companies from using the WhatsApp Business Solution when artificial intelligence is their primary offering. The restrictions take effect January 15, 2026 for existing AI providers, while new providers have been blocked since October 15, 2025. Meta's own AI assistant, Meta AI, remains accessible on the platform.EU antitrust chief Teresa Ribera emphasized the need to prevent dominant digital companies from crowding out innovative competitors, stating regulators must act quickly to prevent irreparable harm to competition in the rapidly expanding AI sector.The policy change has already forced major AI providers to exit WhatsApp. OpenAI 's ChatGPT, which served over 50 million users on the platform, and Microsoft's Copilot both announced they will cease WhatsApp operations by the January deadline. Other third-party AI assistants are expected to follow, leaving Meta AI as the sole chatbot option on the messaging service.Companies can still use AI for secondary functions like automated customer support, but not when AI technology constitutes their core product offering.The Commission's investigation will cover the European Economic Area except Italy, where competition authorities are already pursuing separate proceedings against Meta's conduct. The probe examines whether Meta's restrictions violate Article 102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which prohibits abuse of dominant market position.Meta dismissed the investigation as "baseless," claiming AI chatbots strain systems not designed to support them and asserting the AI market remains highly competitive. The company has not announced changes to its policy despite the regulatory scrutiny.The investigation has no fixed deadline, with duration depending on case complexity and Meta's cooperation with regulators.
Article Summary: European Commission launches formal antitrust investigation into Meta Platforms' policy restricting third-party artificial intelligence providers from accessing WhatsApp's business messaging tools. Meta's October 2025 policy change that prohibits AI companies from using the WhatsApp Business Solution when artificial intelligence is their primary offering. OpenAI's ChatGPT and Microsoft's Copilot both announced they will cease WhatsApp operations by the January deadline.

Article Title: Finternet picks capital markets for first rollout in 2026
Article Text: Bengaluru: Finternet, India’s next big DPI (digital public infrastructure) after UPI, will launch in the capital markets next year, starting with regulated financial assets. More complex areas, including land and real estate, will follow, Principal architect Siddharth Shetty told TOI. The Nandan Nilekani-backed project, built on a Bank for International Settlements blueprint for “unified ledgers”, aims to go live with its first applications next year and ultimately connect tokenised money, securities, and other assets across borders. Nilekani announced the timeline in October at the Global Fintech Fest 2025 in Mumbai. Unified ledgers are shared, programmable platforms that hold tokenised money and financial assets in the same place so they can transact and settle together in real time under common rules. This sequencing marks a pragmatic shift from the headline-grabbing idea of tokenising India’s vast property market, which Nilekani described as a way to “unlock locked assets” in the economy.Regulators and market participants see capital markets as the lower-hanging fruit: titles are clearer, issuers and investors are already highly regulated, and tokenisation pilots, from on-chain fund units to CBDC-based settlement, are underway within the existing securities framework.Shetty described Finternet as an “operating system” for finance, replacing today’s patchwork of siloed rails where “we build a separate road for each car”. In the new design, a single wallet would hold both identity credentials and tokenised assets, allowing individuals and businesses to move seamlessly between apps for property, credit, or investments while using the same underlying infrastructure. That “universal stack,” he argued, would enable AI agents or MSME platforms to tap multiple lenders or investors programmatically, instead of depending on bespoke integrations for one product at a time. “In traditional financial infrastructure, your assets are locked inside one system. Tokenisation is about letting that asset move with you, so an MSME can connect a single invoice to a universe of lenders instead of doing one-off integrations each time,” Shetty said. On land tokenisation, however, Shetty remains cautious. He expects commercial real estate and new primary projects with clean title records to adopt the model first, while legacy residential properties, especially in states with complex title histories, will take much longer. Land remains a state subject, implying a patchwork of early-mover states and laggards rather than a single national rollout. That political and legal complexity is a key reason for capital markets to be the first proving ground.Despite its multi-trillion-dollar ambition, Finternet is currently being built by a roughly 10-member “network of labs” across India, the US, Singapore, and Switzerland, with protocols designed to be asset- and jurisdiction-agnostic from day one. The goal, according to Nilekani and BIS researchers, is a global “network of financial ecosystems” where tokenized assets and programmable money move as easily as data packets on the internet, starting with securities in India’s capital markets before extending to land, gold, and cross-border retail flows.
Article Summary: Finternet, India’s next big DPI (digital public infrastructure) after UPI, will launch in the capital markets next year, starting with regulated financial assets. More complex areas, including land and real estate, will follow. The Nandan Nilekani-backed project is built on a Bank for International Settlements blueprint for ‘unified ledgers’

Article Title: Dream11 pivots to a second screen sports platform
Article Text: Bengaluru: India’s fantasy sports giant, Dream11 , is reinventing itself as a second-screen platform for live sports. It is pitching a new watch-along app that sits alongside broadcasters such as JioCinema and Disney+ Hotstar, rather than streaming matches itself.India’s Online Gaming Bill, passed in August, effectively outlawed Dream11’s core business overnight by imposing a blanket ban on real-money online games, including fantasy sports, poker, and rummy, and barring banks and UPI from processing any such transactions. The legislation explicitly overrode earlier court rulings that treated fantasy as a skill game and carries jail terms and crore-level fines for companies, promoters, and even endorsers who continue to offer money-based contests.Harsh Jain, co-founder and chief executive of parent Dream Sports, told reporters that the new Dream11 is designed as a “second screen dominator experience” that becomes “the best friend” of first-screen broadcasters, much as fantasy sports once boosted viewership. Instead of paid contests, the app hosts live watch-along rooms where creators provide partisan commentary and banter while users track integrated scoreboards, chat, buy virtual shout-outs, or pay to join influencers on stage.“We are moving away from the whole gaming piece altogether,” Jain said, stressing that even where Dream Sports owns rights through its streaming service FanCode, “we will not show their streams” on the new app because it is “meant to be a second-screen sports entertainment platform.”He argued that fantasy sports had a “very positive effect” on viewership and that second-screen engagement can lift sports consumption sharply compared with passive TV watching. The company is launching with around 25 curated creators but plans to open the platform over time, betting that Dream11’s 20-30 million monthly free-to-play users will give influencers instant audiences that rival or exceed watch-along streams on YouTube and Twitch. “No creator wants to come and go live with like 10 people watching,” Jain said. “We have a chance that when we go live for the first match, any creator can come and see a hundred thousand people, maybe a million people have watched them.” Jain cast the product as a fix for what he called the “broken experience” of watching matches alone in a world of nuclear families and scattered friend groups. Fans, he said, want to “watch a match alone at home” but “never want to watch it actually alone,” and are now using WhatsApp, X, and Instagram as crude workarounds.The new Dream11 aims to capture that energy in one place, letting users “watch a match alone together” with the funny or outspoken voices they wish official commentators could be.
Article Summary: India’s fantasy sports giant, Dream11, is reinventing itself as a second-screen platform for live sports. It is pitching a new watch-along app that sits alongside broadcasters such as JioCinema and Disney+ Hotstar, rather than streaming matches itself. Instead of paid contests, the app hosts live watch- along rooms where creators provide partisan commentary.

Article Title: Paramount writes letter to Warner Bros. Discovery on sale process: ‘It has become increasingly clear…’
Article Text:
Warner Bros Discovery (File Image)

Read letter sent by Paramount Skydance to Warner Bros. Discovery



Dear Mr. Zaslav: We write on behalf of

Paramount Skydance Corporation

(“Paramount”, “we” or “us”) to express our serious concerns about the fairness and adequacy of the bidding process for a potential combination with Warner Bros. Discovery (“WBD” or “you”). It has become increasingly clear, through media reporting and otherwise, that WBD appears to have abandoned the semblance and reality of a fair transaction process, thereby abdicating its duties to stockholders, and embarked on a myopic process with a predetermined outcome that favors a single bidder. We specifically request and expect this letter will be shared and discussed with the full board of directors of WBD.

We have recently seen reporting in the U.S. and foreign media that gives serious cause for concern. The German newspaper Handelsblatt recently reported on a meeting that reportedly took place in Brussels between Gerhard Zieler, President of WBD’s International Business and a direct report to WBD’s Chief Executive Officer, who “arrived with a three-person team,” with the E.U. Commission Vice President Hena Virkkunen, to discuss the potential merger prospects for WBD. In that conversation, the article reports that “concerns were raised that the Ellison family’s planned acquisition of Warner Bros. Discovery could lead to excessive media concentration,” and that the E.U. Commission would consider intervening in a potential merger with Paramount for this reason. The article quotes “sources close” to

Zeiler

as saying “that the talks with the Commission were important because both Warner and the EU wanted to preserve media diversity.” The implications of such a meeting, if it occurred, are clear and evince a tacit resistance to, if not active sabotage of, a Paramount offer.

While this report is concerning in itself, this is not an isolated report regarding purported WBD resistance to a combination with Paramount. Several U.S. media outlets have reported on the enthusiasm by WBD management for a transaction with Netflix, and on statements by management that a transaction between WBD and Netflix would be a “slam dunk,” while also referring to Paramount’s bid in a negative light. Additional reporting since the submission of revised bids on December 1 has indicated that WBD’s “board has really warmed to” a transaction with Netflix due to the “chemistry between” WBD management and Netflix management. We have come to you first to inquire whether this reporting is accurate, and to engage in a productive discussion with you around any actual or perceived issues that it may reflect.

Moreover, these media reports echo similar indications that we have been hearing throughout this process, despite what we viewed as otherwise productive conversations that we have had with WBD leadership. Paramount has a credible basis to believe that the sales process has been tainted by management conflicts, including certain members of management’s potential personal interests in post-transaction roles and compensation as a result of the economic incentives embedded in recent amendments to employment arrangements. These concerns are amplified by indications of director bias and beholdenness to others whose interests may not align with the stockholders’, and the fact that alternatives involving only certain WBD assets are being prioritized notwithstanding their heightened regulatory risk and potential to deprive stockholders of consideration for the entirety of WBD’s enterprise value.

Further, as you know, Paramount agreed to certain standstill arrangements in exchange for the opportunity to participate in a truly competitive and unbiased bidding process. Paramount did not bargain for WBD to foster, whether intentionally or unintentionally, a tilted and unfair process. We believe that all parties to this process should have a shared desire for, and will mutually benefit from, an unimpeachable transaction process. As we assume you agree, even discounting the accuracy of any media reports, just the appearance of a flawed process imperils any potential transaction that might result and may undermine the potential value maximization to WBD stockholders from any prospective transaction.

In light of our grave concerns regarding the integrity of WBD’s process, we seek confirmation as to whether WBD has appointed an independent special committee of disinterested members of its board to consider the potential transaction opportunities and to make a final determination regarding a sale or break-up of all or part of the company. If not, we strongly urge you to empower such a special committee comprised of directors with no potential appearance of bias or beholdenness to others whose interests may differ from those of the stockholders. This would seem to be an important step at this stage, to ensure the fairness and unimpeachability of the transaction process and to maximize the value of whatever outcome WBD determines to pursue. Engaging with WBD throughout this process, we have been encouraged by the enormous potential from a combination of our entities. We remain confident that the Paramount offer would provide the maximum value to WBD stockholders and look forward to the opportunity to continue to engage with you productively in this process. But at this point we must insist on assurances and steps taken to ensure that a truly fair and independent process is being conducted, both for Paramount’s benefit and in the interest of WBD’s stockholders.





Paramount Skydance has formally challenged the handling of the sale process for Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) assets, expressing concerns over the fairness of the competition. In a letter, attorneys for Paramount informed WBD CEO David Zaslav that the company is questioning the “fairness and adequacy” of the sale process, which officially started in October.The letter, seen by CNBC, raised concerns regarding media reports suggesting that WBD's management appears to be favouring the offer submitted by Netflix. The letter comes after the second-round bids in which Paramount, Netflix and Comcast submitted offers to acquire some or all of WBD’s assets. Citing sources close to the confidential proceedings, all three companies increased their bids from their initial offers, with Netflix’s bid primarily consisting of cash.
Article Summary: Paramount Skydance sent letter to Warner Bros. Discovery. Letter expresses serious concerns about the fairness and adequacy of the bidding process for a potential combination. Paramount has a credible basis to believe that the sales process has been tainted by management conflicts.

Article Title: Intel makes U-turn, cancels plan to sell its networking division: Read chipmaker’s statement
Article Text:
How ‘new’ financial support has drive a change at Intel







Intel has said that it is shelving plans to spin off or sell a stake in its Networking and Edge Group (NEX) division. The chipmaker said that it is now best positioned to succeed as an internal unit. The decision marks a reversal of a strategy announced earlier this year. The company said it would separate the division and identify strategic investors.“After a thorough review of strategic options for NEX—including a potential standalone path—we determined the business is best positioned to succeed within Intel,” the company said in an emailed statement to Bloomberg.The company previously sought to sell non-core assets, including NEX, to give a boost to its finances after it struggled to keep pace with rivals like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Comapny (TSMC) and Samsung Electronics.“Keeping NEX in-house enables tighter integration between silicon, software and systems, strengthening customer offerings across AI, data center, and edge. As part of the move, Intel ended talks with Ericsson AB, which had discussed buying a stake in NEX,” a spokesperson was quoted as saying. Swedish telecom equipment maker Ericsson relies heavily on Intel-designed chips for several of its mobile network products and had been seeking to ensure the NEX division remained viable.The change in selling strategy comes months after CEO Lip-Bu Tan took the helm in March. While Tan initially focused on cost-cutting measures, including job cuts and offloading non-core assets, the company’s recent influx of capital appears to have altered its trajectory.Intel has received major financial boosts this year, including a 10% equity stake taken by the US government in August, brokered by the Trump administration. Article Title: Billionaires Day Out: Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg and Jeff Bezos turned into bizarre picture-pooping dogs at Art Basel Miami
Article Text:
Elon Musk and Mark Zuckerberg lead Beeple’s robot pack

Mark Zuckerberg unveils three new Meta AI smart glasses

Robots with a built-in expiry date

A moment that reflects our digital era









At Art Basel Miami, one of the world’s biggest and flashiest art fairs, a strange group of robotic dogs has become the biggest attraction. These dogs are not ordinary machines. They wear lifelike silicone faces of famous people including Elon Musk Jeff Bezos , Andy Warhol, Pablo Picasso and even the artist Beeple himself. They walk around, blink, and sometimes lean back to “poop” printed artworks. The installation, called Regular Animals, mixes humour, technology and social commentary, and it is almost impossible to walk past without staring.On opening day, crowds gathered around the pen where the robot dogs wandered about. People laughed, filmed on their phones and reacted with shock and confusion. The Musk robot puckered its lips, the Picasso robot gazed into space, and the Beeple robot stopped mid-walk to drop a freshly printed NFT for visitors to take.Beeple, whose real name is Mike Winkelmann, stood inside the enclosure picking up the printed artworks and handing them to the audience. These prints are not just souvenirs. They are NFTs stored on the blockchain, continuing Beeple’s interest in digital art and how technology shapes creativity.“They are constantly taking pictures and reinterpreting the world through the lens of these different characters,” Winkelmann explained.Each robot sees the world differently, depending on the style of the person it represents, whether that is Warhol’s bright colours, Picasso’s abstract shapes or the digital influence of tech billionaires.The Musk, Zuckerberg and Bezos robots highlight Beeple’s point about how much power tech leaders have over what billions of people see online. By turning them into robot dogs, he turns that idea into something funny, strange and slightly unsettling.Beeple became world-famous in 2021 when his digital collage Everydays: The First 5000 Days sold for 69.3 million dollars at Christie’s, making him one of the most valuable living artists. The NFT market later crashed, which Beeple himself predicted, saying there had been far too much low-quality work at the time.But digital art has continued to grow. Art Basel’s 2025 report says the field is expanding again, and the fair has a new section called Zero 10 dedicated to digital and tech-based art. This is where Regular Animals has become the most talked-about installation.Visitors reacted in very different ways. Some called it disgusting or disturbing. Others found it brilliant and hilarious. At one point, two real dogs wandered into the area and barked at the robotic versions, which amused the crowd even more.Beeple designed the robots with a limited lifespan. Their main function, which is to take photos and turn them into NFTs, will stop after three years. They will still be able to walk, but their creative output will end. It is a reminder of how fast technology ages and becomes outdated.Despite that, all the robots were sold within the first hour of the fair. Soon, small versions of the Zuckerbergs, Musks and Warhols will be living in private homes, occasionally producing NFTs as they move around.Beeple’s installation captures the strange way art, technology and culture mix in 2025. It is funny, weird and clever, and it forces people to think about how much influence tech giants have over modern life.Beeple’s installation warns, “We are not ready for the future.” Judging from the shocked faces, laughter and constant filming at Art Basel Miami, that message seems to be landing exactly as he intended.
Article Summary: Beeple’s installation captures the strange way art, technology and culture mix in 2025. They wear lifelike silicone faces of famous people including Elon Musk, Andy Warhol, Pablo Picasso and even the artist Beeple himself. They walk around, blink, and sometimes lean back to “poop” printed artworks.

Article Title: After blocking WhatsApp and YouTube, Russia bans one of iPhone’s ‘biggest’ features, here’s why
Article Text:

Russia tightens control over foreign technology









Russia has blocked access to Apple 's video-calling app, FaceTime, the country’s communications watchdog Roskomnadzor announced on Thursday (December 4). The move targets one of the iPhone’s core features and comes after the Kremlin has clamped down on foreign technology platforms like Google's YouTube, Meta-owned WhatsApp and Telegram.According to a report by news agency Reuters, Roskomnadzor justified its decision by claiming the app was being misused for illegal activities. FaceTime, which allows users to make free video and audio calls over the internet. “According to law enforcement agencies, FaceTime is being used to organize and carry out terrorist attacks in the country, recruit perpetrators, and commit fraud and other crimes against Russian citizens,” the regulator said in an emailed statement to Reuters.Moscow residents attempting to use the service reported seeing an on-screen message stating “User unavailable.” Some users even claimed that they saw an incoming call notification but were unable to connect.The blocking of FaceTime is the latest in a series of measures by Roskomnadzor against Western tech platforms accused of hosting content that breaches Russian laws. Notably, earlier this year, Russia began limiting some calls on WhatsApp and Telegram, accusing the services of refusing to share critical information with law enforcement related to fraud and terrorism cases.Roskomnadzor even threatened to block WhatsApp completely last week.Russia has also launched a state-backed rival application called MAX, which critics allege could be used for surveillance. Just one day prior to the FaceTime block, Roskomnadzor also blocked access to the US children's gaming platform Roblox, accusing it of distributing extremist materials and "LGBT propaganda."

Article Title: Australia’s internet regulator says social media ban for teens will trigger global pushback against Facebook, Instagram, YouTube and others
Article Text:
Big Tech comply with Australia social media ban as December 10 deadline nears







Australia’s internet regulator has said that the country’s ban on social media access for children under the age of 16 will be the first crucial step in a global effort to curb the influence of major technology companies like Meta (Instagram, Facebook, and Threads), TikTok, Snap’s Snapchat, and Alphabet’s YouTube.“We’ve reached a tipping point,” According to eSafety Commissioner Julie Inman Grant stated at the Sydney Dialogue cyber summit. Notably, she initially had concerns about the “blunt-force” nature of the ban but now fully supports it after incremental changes proved ineffective in regulating platforms.“Our data is the currency that fuels these companies, and there are these powerful, harmful, deceptive design features that even adults are powerless to fight against. What chance do our children have?” she said, as per news agency Reuters.As per Grant, the Australian legislation is the “first domino” in a global regulatory shift. She noted that governments worldwide are closely observing its implementation. She even suggested that this global domino effect may be the reason why platforms “pushed back” against the law so strongly.The pushback included lobbying efforts that reached the US government, the report said.Inman Grant revealed that she has been asked to testify at the U.S. congressional House Judiciary regarding what some critics have termed an attempt to exert extra-territorial power over American free speech.The Australian law is set to take effect on December 10. Ahead of the deadline, the Big Tech social media platforms have agreed to comply. The eSafety Commissioner reported that approximately 96% of Australian teenagers under 16, which is over a million users, have social media accounts. The report said that Meta’s Instagram, Facebook and Threads has already begun deactivating hundreds of thousands of accounts on Thursday (December 4).Furthermore, most other affected platforms have advised underage users to download their data and offered them the choice of deleting their accounts or freeze them until they turn 16. Meanwhile, some parents in Austrailia welcomed the ban.
Article Summary: The Australian law is set to take effect on December 10. Ahead of the deadline, the Big Tech social media platforms have agreed to comply. The eSafety Commissioner reported that approximately 96% of Australian teenagers under 16, which is over a million users, have social media accounts.

Article Title: Bill Gates ‘warns’ Donald Trump: US will share blame for rising child deaths as…
Article Text:
Bill Gates warns President Trump that slashing US global health funding could cause the first rise in childhood deaths this century. New projections indicate millions more children may die if cuts persist. While the Gates Foundation is increasing its own spending, it cannot replace government support, leaving vulnerable nations struggling to achieve self-sufficiency.

Global health aid plummets 27% amid international retreat

Foundation doubles spending as government support evaporates





Bill Gates has delivered a stark warning to President Donald Trump : deep cuts to US global health funding could make America culpable for the first increase in childhood deaths this century. Gates revealed he told Trump that modest cuts of 10-20% might be justified for efficiency, but anything beyond that level would give the US "some culpability in the increase in deaths. " The president responded favorably, Gates said, "but we don't have a plan to get the spending all back in place."The warning comes as new modeling projects 4.8 million children will die before their fifth birthday in 2025—an increase of more than 200,000 from last year. If funding cuts persist at 20%, an additional 12 million children could die by 2045, according to the Gates Foundation's annual Goalkeepers report.Global aid funding has dropped almost 27% this year, devastating programs that depended on sustained support. While Trump's dismantling of USAID has drawn attention, the UK, France, and Germany have also slashed spending dramatically.The impact is already visible on the ground. In Nigeria alone, donor-funded programs that once employed over 8,000 tuberculosis workers have ended, which Gates said will lead to tens of thousands of additional deaths from a single disease in one country.The Microsoft co-founder emphasized that routine vaccination remains the most cost-effective intervention, with every dollar spent returning $54 in benefits. However, vaccine skepticism promoted by US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. threatens to undermine progress globally.Gates stressed that while the Gates Foundation plans to double its spending over the next two decades, private philanthropy cannot compensate for the US government pullback. For poor African countries, achieving self-sufficiency is a 20-year goal, not a four-year one, he noted.Despite expressing guarded optimism about some aspects of the State Department's new global health strategy, Gates acknowledged the uncertain path forward: "I do think that Congress cares and President Trump cares, but we still don't have a full resolution of what the funding flows will look like."
Article Summary: Gates warns US global health funding cuts could cause first rise in childhood deaths this century. New projections indicate millions more children may die if cuts persist. Article Title: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff comforts investors as AI jitters wipe away more than $100 billion in shareholder wealth; says: We all know that ...
Article Text:
Salesforce big bet on AI agents





Salesforce posted better-than-expected quarterly results this week, giving CEO Marc Benioff fresh ammunition to push back against a wave of investor skepticism regarding the company's aggressive pivot toward artificial intelligence. The business software giant reported earnings that eclipsed analyst projections, offering a potential reprieve for a stock that has been hammered recently by doubts over whether the industry's massive spending on AI will yield profitable returns.Despite the earnings beat, the modest market reaction highlights the persistent doubts hanging over the technology sector. Investors have grown increasingly wary of the hundreds of billions of dollars being poured into AI infrastructure without immediate signs of a commensurate financial payoff. Salesforce too has been feeling the pressure of AI jitters acutely. Before earnings report, the company's market value had plunged 35% from a peak of $369 per share a year ago, wiping out approximately $125 billion in shareholder wealth. Even Nvidia, the dominant chipmaker powering the AI boom, has not been immune to the volatility. Despite soaring past earnings estimates two weeks ago, Nvidia's stock remains 15% below its late October peak.For the quarter ending in October, the San Francisco-based company earned $2.1 billion, or $2.19 per share, marking a 37% increase from the same period last year. Revenue rose 9% to nearly $10.9 billion. Salesforce also issued a forecast for the current quarter that exceeded Wall Street predictions. "We're uniquely positioned for this new era," Benioff said during a 25-minute address on an analyst conference call.Benioff, who co-founded Salesforce in 1999 and helped pioneer the shift to cloud computing, characterized the company’s new technology as generating "wow" moments for customers. Shares of Salesforce initially surged more than 5% following the report but pared gains to 2% after Benioff’s presentation.Salesforce has focused its strategy on "Agentforce," a suite of AI agents designed to automate customer sales and support tasks. In a move highlighting the potential for this technology to replace human labor, the company recently laid off 4,000 of its own customer support workers as its AI tools took over those responsibilities.However, corporate adoption has been slower than anticipated. Jay Woods, chief market strategist for Freedom Capital Markets, told news agency AP that as customers haven't embraced AI agents as quickly as investors hoped, Salesforce has become a "poster child" for the doubts hanging over the technology."We all know that the speed of innovation has exceeded the speed of customer adoption," Benioff acknowledged Wednesday, though he predicted this dynamic would change as more organizations integrate AI into their operations.Benioff also highlighted the company's long-term growth targets, projecting $60 billion in revenue for the fiscal year ending in January 2030. To reach that goal, the company needs to maintain average annual increases of 10% from its current fiscal year forecast of $41.5 billion.The company also recently completed an $8 billion acquisition of Informatica, a software maker building AI tools for corporate data management. "We're continuing to execute on the path to our $60 billion dream," Benioff said.
Article Summary: Salesforce posted better-than-expected quarterly results this week. CEO Marc Benioff wants to push back against investor skepticism regarding the company's aggressive pivot toward artificial intelligence. Salesforce has focused its strategy on "Agentforce," a suite of AI agents designed to automate customer sales.

Article Title: GM CEO says to set the record straight, She privately talked to Biden on Elon Musk; told him Tesla…
Article Text:
General Motors CEO Mary Barra revealed she privately corrected President Biden after a 2021 White House event that excluded Tesla. Barra told Biden that Tesla deserved recognition for its EV advancements, a sentiment echoed by Kamala Harris who later acknowledged the snub. This exclusion fueled a rift between Biden and Elon Musk, impacting political alliances and EV policy debates.

Tesla snub sparked years-long political fallout

Trump administration reverses EV policy direction





General Motors CEO Mary Barra revealed Wednesday that she privately corrected then-President Joe Biden after a controversial 2021 White House event that excluded Tesla and Elon Musk , telling him that Tesla deserved recognition for advancing electric vehicles in America.Speaking at The New York Times DealBook Summit, Barra disclosed that when Biden credited her with leading the EV revolution, she responded: "Actually, I think a lot of that credit goes to Elon and Tesla." The GM chief had previously stated she hadn't given much thought to the May 2021 White House EV summit snub, even as her company received presidential praise.The exclusion of Tesla—the world's largest EV producer—from the summit became a pivotal moment that contributed to a massive rift between Biden and Musk, who later campaigned for Donald Trump and briefly served as a key White House advisor earlier this year.Musk made no secret of his anger, writing in December 2021 that the White House gave Tesla "the cold shoulder" while crediting GM with leading the electric car revolution "in the same quarter that they delivered 26 electric cars (not a typo) and Tesla delivered 300 thousand." Even Vice President Kamala Harris later acknowledged the mistake, writing in her campaign book: "If you are convening the nation's manufacturers of electric vehicles and the biggest player in the field is not there, it simply doesn't make sense.The political landscape has shifted dramatically since 2021. Recent tensions between Trump and Musk erupted over Trump's "Big, Beautiful Bill," with the president calling Musk "crazy" and threatening to cut government contracts with his companies after Musk criticized the legislation's impact on federal deficits.The dispute centered on the bill's elimination of the $7,500 EV tax credit, though Musk has maintained he supports removing the subsidies, stating "take away the subsidies. It will only help Tesla." However, analysts now suggest that Tesla's recent sales troubles mean the company "needs all the demand help it can get."
Article Summary: General Motors CEO Mary Barra revealed she privately corrected then-President Joe Biden after a 2021 White House event that excluded Tesla. Barra told Biden that Tesla deserved recognition for its EV advancements, a sentiment echoed by Kamala Harris. This exclusion fueled a rift between Biden and Elon Musk, impacting political alliances and EV policy debates.
